headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Oct. 12-13, 2019

headline: American Swimmer Conor Dwyer Gets 20-Month Suspension
summary: American Conor Dwyer, a three-time Olympic medalist swimmer, received a 20-month suspension Friday after an arbitration panel concluded he had testosterone pellets inserted in his body.

headline: Boeing Strips CEO of Chairman’s Job
summary: Boeing’s board stripped CEO Dennis Muilenburg of his dual role as chairman following two deadly crashes of its 737 MAX jet.

headline: Major Blue Health Insurers Drop Deal to Combine
summary: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of North Carolina and Cambia Health Solutions said they were dropping plans to combine, after the resignation of the North Carolina insurer’s chief executive.

headline: PG&E, Apple, Bed Bath & Beyond: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week’s news

headline: FAA, Boeing Criticized for Oversights in MAX’s Design
summary: An international panel of experts said inadequate U.S. safety oversight, combined with Boeing’s failure to properly assess and communicate important design changes, contributed to two fatal crashes of the company’s 737 MAX aircraft.

headline: Some Vaping Patients Return to Hospitals
summary: Some patients released from the hospital after suffering from vaping-related illnesses had to be readmitted after relapses, underlining the challenges of treating the mysterious lung injuries.

headline: Fox News Anchor Shepard Smith Steps Down After 23 Years on the Air
summary: Fox News Channel anchor Shepard Smith is leaving the network he has been a part of since it launched in 1996.

headline: Bankruptcy Judge Pushes Purdue Into Talks With States Over Sackler Family Legal Shield
summary: A bankruptcy judge granted a brief legal reprieve to the Sackler family, owners of Purdue Pharma, shielding them from answering in court for their alleged role in feeding the nationwide opioid crisis.

headline: Barneys Bankruptcy Lenders Extend Bid Deadline Until Tuesday
summary: Barneys New York’s lenders extended until Tuesday a deadline for the luxury retailer to clinch an offer from a buyer.

headline: Andy Rubin Departs From Playground Global
summary: Android software creator Andy Rubin has left Playground Global, the venture-capital firm he co-founded.

headline: The Turk and the President
summary: The Syrian retreat is all too typical of Trump’s decision-making.

headline: The Electric-Vehicle Subsidy Racket
summary: The $7,500 tax credit is going to many buyers who don’t qualify.

headline: Beto O’Rourke’s Progressive Tolerance
summary: Now he wants to use the tax code to punish religious dissenters.

headline: SEC Sues Crypto Startup Telegram Over Initial Coin Offering
summary: U.S. regulators sued a company that raised $1.7 billion through a cryptocurrency offering that became one of the largest such deals ever.

headline: Photos of the Week
summary: Turkey begins offensive in Syria, PG&E power outage in California affects millions, Simone Biles shatters gymnastic records and more from The Wall Street Journal’s photo editors.

headline: Financial Adviser Pleads Guilty to Facilitating Bribes in Ecuador
summary: Frank Roberto Chatburn Ripalda pleaded guilty in a federal court in Miami to one count of conspiracy to commit money laundering as part of a scheme that involved paying bribes to officials at Ecuador’s state oil company.

headline: Appeals Court Says House Can Subpoena Trump Accounting Records
summary: A federal appeals court ruled a House committee can subpoena President Trump’s financial records from his longtime accounting firm, a win for congressional Democrats that is likely to be appealed to the Supreme Court.

headline: Millennials Are Coming to America’s Small Towns
summary: We moved beyond the suburbs so that we can breathe free, park without worry and enjoy a parade.

headline: NotableQuotable: Michael M. Uhlmann, RIP
summary: ‘We cannot say for sure what forms presidential ambition will take under direct election.’

headline: Social-Justice Warriors Won’t Listen, but You Should
summary: To counter extreme views, it’s necessary for you to understand them—and that they’re sincerely held.

headline: Do California’s Blackouts Make Sense?
summary: Some 90% of wildfires are not caused by power lines. How does cutting power help fight them?

headline: ‘Music’ Review: Posterity Without Pedestals
summary: Even Bach was once a rule-breaker, whose bold music disturbed Leipzig’s austere Lutherans.

headline: ‘The Topeka School’ Review: Lost Boys on the Prairie
summary: For his third novel, Ben Lerner expands his canvas to produce a polyphonic portrait of an entire community, yet never strays far from the autobiographical.

headline: First Parent to Avoid Prison in College-Admissions Scandal
summary: A Bay Area father is the first to avoid prison in the nationwide college-admissions scandal, after a federal judge credited him for not hiding his payment as a charitable donation.

headline: Ukrainians vs. the Swamp
summary: Encouraging signs that someday the country might not even tolerate a Hunter Biden deal.

headline: Pentagon to Deploy Around 2,000 Additional Troops to Saudi Arabia
summary: The Pentagon is deploying three antimissile systems, two squadrons of jet fighters and some 2,000 additional troops to Saudi Arabia in a buildup meant to counter Iran.

headline: Brexit Bounce: U.K. Assets Surge on Divorce-Deal Optimism
summary: Signs of optimism that the U.K. could reach a divorce deal with the European Union drove the pound and U.K bank stocks sharply higher.

headline: Citibank Fined $30 Million in Real-Estate Holding Rules Case
summary: A U.S. banking regulator has fined an arm of Citigroup $30 million, saying it violated holding period regulations on foreclosed real estate.

headline: Giuliani’s Longtime Business Partner Resigns From Security Firm
summary: Rudy Giuliani’s longtime business partner and friend, John Huvane, resigned from their security company in recent weeks, according to several people familiar with the move, which Mr. Giuliani confirmed.

headline: Stocks Rally as U.S.-China Trade Talks Progress
summary: U.S. stocks surged as investors cheered progress on trade negotiations between the U.S. and China, helping the S&P 500 break a three-week losing streak.

headline: Government-Bond Yields Climb on Trade Talks, Brexit
summary: Government-bond yields around the world rose, as investors embraced signs of progress in trade talks between the U.S. and China and in Brexit negotiations.

headline: Apple Breaks Out of the ‘FAANG’ Stock Slump
summary: Apple shares set a new all-time high and have recently outperformed their peers in the popular “FAANG” trade.

headline: Attorney Bill Urquhart Thrived as a Recruiter of Other Lawyers
summary: A big league litigator, Bill Urquhart was even better known for his ability to recruit lawyers to his firm, Quinn Emanuel. Wearing Hawaiian shirts and flip-flops, he sometimes offered margaritas to job candidates. He died Oct. 4 at age 72.

headline: Red Hat CFO Loses Out on Retention Bonus Following Standards-Related Ouster
summary: Red Hat’s finance chief Eric Shander has been dismissed from the company, forfeiting a $4 million retention award that was agreed to ahead of Red Hat’s acquisition by International Business Machines.

headline: Plucked From Life
summary: Bernardo Strozzi’s ‘The Cook’ is revolutionary in its humble subject matter and very human protagonist.

headline: Judges Block Rule to Disqualify Legal Immigrants Over Public Assistance
summary: Federal judges in three states blocked a Trump administration rule that would disqualify legal immigrants from permanent residency if they use certain public-assistance programs.

headline: Fed Will Purchase Treasury Bills at Least Into Second Quarter of 2020
summary: The Federal Reserve said it would begin buying Treasury bills on Tuesday to boost its balance sheet and avoid a recurrence of the unexpected strains experienced in money markets last month.

headline: Oil Prices Climb After Iranian Tanker Damaged in Possible Strike
summary: Oil prices climbed after an Iranian tanker near the Saudi Arabian coast suffered damage in what the ship’s owner suggested may have been a missile attack.

headline: Trump Taps Pompeo Deputy as Russian Envoy
summary: President Trump has tapped John Sullivan, currently the deputy Secretary of State, to serve as the U.S. ambassador to Russia, the White House said.

headline: Kohl’s Promotes Finance Veteran to CFO in Effort to Boost Customer Traffic
summary: Kohl’s promoted a finance veteran to the role of finance chief as the company looks to cut costs and boost customer traffic after a stretch of sluggish sales, analysts say.

headline: California Bans Private Prisons, Immigrant Detention Centers
summary: California will work to end the use of private prisons within its borders, including for-profit immigrant detention facilities, under a law signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom.

headline: Diagnoses of the State of Cancer Treatments
summary: A rational approach to early cancer detection could include focusing on individuals who have the highest genetic predisposition to cancer or tumor types with the longest lead times to metastasis.

headline: Sports Illustrated Prospered When It Was Mostly Sports
summary: Editors decided to drift away from reporting strictly on the sports world and became an active participant in social activism.

headline: Bureaucrats for Homeless Have the Wrong Incentives
summary: The primary beneficiaries of the money spent on San Francisco’s homelessness problem are the people handing out the needles and the jerky.

headline: China’s Old Debt to the U.S.
summary: The Chinese would be speaking Japanese now were it not for the good old U.S.A.

headline: GM Talks With UAW Hit Impasse, Propelling Strike Into the Weekend
summary: General Motors and the United Auto Workers accused each other of not working hard enough to reach a new four-year contract, end the 26-day strike and put 46,000 full-time factory employees back to work.

headline: Appeals Panel Questions Proposal to Limit Exchange Trading Fees
summary: Judges for a federal appeals court debated Friday whether federal regulators justified a pilot program that would limit the trading fees stock exchanges charge.

headline: IAC Proposes to Spin Off Match
summary: IAC has made a proposal to Match’s board to spin off its interest in the online-dating giant to its shareholders.

headline: EU Warns of 5G Risks Amid Scrutiny of Huawei
summary: The European Union has identified specific security threats posed by foreign vendors of telecommunications equipment, significantly heightening the bloc’s scrutiny of suppliers like Huawei Technologies.

headline: Spending by the Sweetgreen Elite May Not Be Sustainable
summary: Salad chain Sweetgreen is bringing a whole new meaning to the overpriced desk salad, and its customers are eating it up.

headline: Police Arrest Man on Suspicion of Terrorism After Stabbings in U.K.
summary: Police arrested a man on suspicion of terrorism offenses following a series of stabbings at a shopping center in Manchester, northwest England, that left four people wounded.

headline: Schedule Unveiled for 2020 General Election Debates
summary: The Commission on Presidential Debates unveiled a schedule of three general-election debates and one vice presidential debate, the first of which is slated for Sept. 29 at the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind.

headline: When God Is Your Portfolio Manager
summary: Biblically responsible investing is booming, as some Christians move to match their faith with their stock buys.

headline: U.S. Sanctions South Sudanese Businessmen for Alleged Corruption
summary: The U.S. Treasury Department imposed sanctions on two South Sudanese businessmen and several of their companies for alleged corruption and urged the government to take immediate action against systemic bribery.

headline: A Black Crowes Reunion Tour? The Music Business Is Abuzz
summary: Ahead of the 30th anniversary of the Crowes’ debut album, industry insiders say they are hearing about a possible reconciliation of the band’s famously feuding brothers, Chris and Rich Robinson.

headline: TP ICAP Pays £15.4 Million Over U.K. Investigation Into Broker Misconduct
summary: TP ICAP said it has agreed to pay a £15.4 million fine to settle an investigation by the U.K.’s Financial Conduct Authority into trades undertaken between 2008 and 2011.

headline: Uber to Acquire Majority Stake in Grocery-Delivery Service Cornershop
summary: Uber is buying a majority stake in grocery-delivery company Cornershop, as the company continues to expand its reach beyond the core ride-hailing business.

headline: Reynolds Files for FDA Review of Vuse E-Cigarettes
summary: Tobacco giant Reynolds submitted an application for some of its Vuse e-cigarettes to the FDA,seeking permission to keep its vaping products on the market.

headline: A Vision of the NBA’s Future Political Agenda
summary: Looking ahead to the day when the league finally takes a stand against…Indiana.

headline: AI Could Prevent Marital Arguments Before They Even Begin
summary: Researchers use listening devices and algorithms to detect speech patterns that typically precede fights.

headline: An Ad Giant Struggles To Sell Its Story
summary: Publicis, which owns brands like Leo Burnett and Sapient, has misstepped in its digital transformation

headline: Five Best: Caitlin Horrocks on Biographical Novels About Artists
summary: The author, most recently, of the novel “The Vexations,” selects fictional works about real creative lives.

headline: ‘The Body’ Review: The Magnificent Machine
summary: Evolution runs on imperfect ‘make-do,’ Bill Bryson stresses. Humans learned to walk upright, at the cost of fragile joints and clog-prone sinuses.

headline: ‘The Nature of Life and Death’ Review: The Queen of Forensic Science
summary: Patricia Wiltshire helps find perpetrators by analyzing the dust, dirt and pollen they leave at crime scenes.

headline: Fiction: Life Without Illusions in Crosby, Maine
summary: The return of the tart-tongued Olive Kitteridge, who remains as brutally candid with herself as she is with others.

headline: Mysteries: Getting Pragmatic With the Law
summary: The gregarious Constable Peregrine Twitten annoys his colleagues with pesky questions about the apparent suicide of a Brighton beachgoer.

headline: Brexit Talks to Intensify as Prospect of Deal Improves
summary: European Union and U.K. officials will intensify Brexit talks in an attempt to reach an agreement on Britain’s split from the bloc before a leaders’ summit next week.

headline: Children’s Books: Goblins, Dragons, Trolls—and Some Humans Too
summary: Celebrating myths and fables from Scotland, England, Ireland, Norway, Switzerland, Korea and even more countries.

headline: The Search For Billy
summary: Theresa and Bill Reilly found the beach on the Don River where Billy took a photo he texted them of a residential clock tower.

headline: Billy Is Found
summary: On June 3, Theresa and William Reilly arrived at the morgue and crematorium in Rostov-on-Don to claim the body of their son, Billy. Their search ended four years after his last text home.

headline: ‘Kangaroo Court’: A Peculiar Complaint of Unjust Proceedings
summary: The expression used by President Trump to denounce impeachment seems to come from the antebellum American South, with a dark connection to lynching

headline: Billy Reilly’s Childhood
summary: Billy Reilly growing up in Oxford, Mich., “always wanted something bigger than our lives,” his sister said. The 9/11 terrorist attacks directed his curiosity to Islam and led him to study Arabic and Russian languages.

headline: Matthew Jenkins Found Gold in Mobile-Home Communities
summary: Matthew Jenkins thrived as a veterinarian by keeping his clinic open overnight and on weekends—then he built a chain of mobile-home parks and  funded math education in public schools.

headline: Canada Added More Jobs Than Expected in September
summary: Canada’s labor market posted another strong advance in September and the unemployment rate unexpectedly fell to 5.5%, fueling expectations the Bank of Canada will leave interest rates on hold in its upcoming decision.

headline: Investors Approve UTC-Raytheon Merger
summary: Shareholders backed the creation of one of the world’s largest aerospace companies, voting in favor of the $135 billion combination of United Technologies and Raytheon.

headline: Best-Selling Books Week Ended October 5
summary: With data from NPD BookScan

headline: Trump Makes Joe Biden’s Son a Top Campaign Target
summary: President Trump took aim at the son of former Vice President Joe Biden, ridiculing the 49-year-old as a loser, accusing him of profiting off his father’s name and turning him into a campaign prop during a rally in Minnesota.

headline: New York Fed Adds $82.7 Billion To Financial System in Latest Repo Transaction
summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $82.7 billion to the financial system Friday, using the market for repurchase agreements, or repo, to relieve funding pressure in money markets.

headline: Nobel Peace Prize Awarded to Ethiopian Prime Minister
summary: Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday for his work toward ending a 20-year conflict with neighboring Eritrea and opening up one of Africa’s most notorious one-party systems.

headline: Zillow Still Looks Like a Fixer-Upper
summary: Zillow’s shares look as discounted as the fees on the homes Zillow is selling, but they still may not find many motivated buyers.

headline: Should Aging Parents Have to Pay the Check?

headline: Schumer Threatens Procedural Move to Save Obama’s Climate Rules
summary: Impeachment politics hasn’t distracted senators from at least one of their favorite pastimes: procedural gamesmanship.

headline: Languages of Pure Form and Color
summary: Pierre Bonnard and Édouard Vuillard charted art’s course toward abstraction

headline: Hugo Boss Is a Bad Fit for a Weaker Economy
summary: Spending at companies like Hugo Boss is drying up more quickly than at ultra-luxury brands. Premium fashion labels will be especially vulnerable in the next economic downturn.

headline: Stocks to Watch: U.S. Steel, Fastenal, SAP and More
summary: Fastenal, SAP SE, United States Steel and Bed Bath & Beyond are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Friday.

headline: Renault Board Votes to Remove CEO Bolloré
summary: Renault fired Chief Executive Thierry Bolloré as the French car maker seeks to turn the page on auto titan Carlos Ghosn’s decades of leadership and reboot its globe-spanning alliance with Nissan.

summary: Houston was pushed to the brink by Tampa Bay, but its elite starting pitching, led by Gerrit Cole, is why the Astros are still the team to beat.

summary: The Washington Redskins and the Miami Dolphins will play a real-life professional football game this weekend. There will be referees, some fans and one of the teams should even get a win.

headline: Deborah Norville on the Pitfalls of Landing Your Dream Job
summary: The longtime anchor of syndicated television show “Inside Edition” knows what it’s like to land a dream job and then lose it.

headline: Earnings Season May Not Be as Bad as Investors Think
summary: With less than a week to go before third-quarter earnings season kicks off, analysts estimate companies in the S&P 500 will report a 4.5% drop in profits. But for some, those estimates look far too pessimistic.

summary: How the obsessions of Jim Ratcliffe and Eliud Kipchoge aligned for Saturday’s attempt on one of running’s last barriers.

summary: China and President Trump would both benefit from a truce focused on food purchases, but investors risk overestimating the economic impact.

headline: A Private-Equity Partnership With Richard Branson Stalls
summary: London-based Metric Capital Partners hoped to raise $500 million for a private-equity fund in partnership with the U.K. billionaire to back fast-growing consumer brands across Europe and the U.S. But the partnership hasn’t gone as planned.

summary: The painter and sculptor shares the personal objects that inspire her most, including a 100-carat ring her husband, artist John Currin, once gave her

summary: At town-hall gatherings with GOP members of Congress, Republicans criticize the impeachment probe but Democrats press their representatives to back the investigation.

headline: On Edge from Attacks, Germany Finds Far-Right Radicals Within Security Services
summary: German security officials are investigating their own ranks for far-right extremists and terror suspects, alarmed by a surge in attacks on migrants and politicians that exposed radical views among police officers and elite special forces.

headline: She Took a Two-Year Break in Her Career. Now She’s CEO.
summary: Deanna Mulligan of Guardian Life Insurance talks about how time off helped her find new focus.

headline: Publicis Shares Plunge After Ad Giant Cuts Guidance
summary: Shares in Publicis dropped sharply after the advertising giant lowered its guidance for the second time in a year, stoking fears about the ad industry’s ability to cope with a host of challenges including the increasing dominance of tech giants.

headline: Acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan to Step Down
summary: Acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan is leaving his post after months of tension with the White House over its hard-line immigration strategy.

headline: Trump Pressed for Ukraine Envoy’s Removal, She Tells Lawmakers
summary: President Trump for more than a year had pressured the State Department to remove the former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, the envoy told lawmakers from both parties in more than nine hours of closed-door testimony that Democrats demanded as part of their rapidly expanding impeachment inquiry.

headline: Los Angeles Fire Forces Thousands to Evacuate as Power Returns for Some in Northern California
summary: Deadly wildfires fueled by dry, powerful winds burned through Southern California Friday, punctuating a week of preventive power blackouts that have redefined a new normal for fire prevention in the state.

headline: U.S. Threatens Turkey With Sanctions
summary: President Trump plans to sign an executive order that lets the U.S. impose new sanctions on Turkey following its decision to launch military operations this week against U.S.-allied Kurdish forces in Syria.

headline: Mastercard, Visa, eBay Drop Out of Facebook's Libra Payments Network
summary: The biggest financial companies recruited by Facebook to launch a cryptocurrency-based payments network have backed out of the project, threatening to derail an ambitious initiative to remake global finance.

headline: Whistleblowers and the Real Deep State
summary: Civil servants too often forget they work for the people and seek to impose their own policy agendas.

headline: Indicted Donors Spread Campaign Cash Widely
summary: At least 14 Republican candidates and groups directly received a total of $675,500 in campaign contributions last year from Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman, the Soviet-born Florida businessmen indicted this week on campaign-finance violations.

headline: Lawmakers Seek U.S. Creditor Shield for Venezuela’s Citgo
summary: Seven mostly Republican lawmakers urged President Trump to shield Citgo Petroleum from a potential $900 million bond default and keep the company under the control of Venezuela’s U.S.-backed opposition government.

headline: The Houston Rockets Were China’s Team. Then a Hong Kong Tweet Happened.
summary: The standoff between the NBA and Beijing appears to be cooling, but the consequences will linger for the team at the center of the storm.

headline: NATO Chastises Turkey Over Syria, but Fears Driving It Toward Russia
summary: Turkey’s military incursion into northern Syria triggered a new rift between Ankara and its NATO allies, highlighting a growing divergence on security concerns and complicating efforts to thwart an increasingly assertive Russia.

headline: Range Rover’s New Hybrid: Already Five Years Behind the Curve
summary: With techy car brands like Tesla pushing all-electric range well past 200 miles, the Range Rover Sport PHEV’s estimated 25-mile ability falls woefully short. Dan Neil takes it for a spin.

headline: Streaming Is Killing Physical Media. Here’s Why You Won’t Miss It.
summary: With Samsung’s decision to stop making Blu-ray players, now even discs are going extinct. One writer reminisces about all we’ll lose. Another looks forward to an all-digital future.

headline: Ukraine Tries to Build a New Identity
summary: Long in Russia’s shadow, the country has rejected ethnic  politics in favor of inclusion, economic growth and cultural diversity

headline: A Norway Cruise That Offers Flexibility and Very Little Fuss
summary: On a series of cruise-like ferry trips up Norway’s coastline, a visitor hops on and off as she likes, seeking out snug spots with overwhelming views.

summary: As robots take on bigger roles, it’s crucial that users trust and like them. That can be tricky.

summary: A preacher’s son, a small-town man at heart, Frank Lloyd Wright created secular cathedrals that seem to hover like recently landed spaceships, defying gravity.

headline: The FBI Lost Our Son
summary: Billy Reilly, 28 years old, worked part-time as a confidential source for the Detroit office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. For years, he penetrated radical internet groups online, using false identities. Then he disappeared.

summary: The future of artificial intelligence depends on designing computers that can think and explore as resourcefully as babies do.

summary: The War of 1812 was already over, but victory at New Orleans filled the young U.S. with swagger and a sense of destiny.

headline: Secret Recordings Describe Extensive Corruption at Mexico’s Pemex
summary: Officials at the state-run oil company describe widespread bribery and corruption in secret audio tapes that are part of evidence in a lawsuit against the Mexican government. Oil-field drilling company Oro Negro says Pemex  helped drive it intobankruptcy because the driller refused to pay bribes.

summary: Today’s Top Supply Chain & Logistics News from WSJ.

summary: The loudest complaints against today’s monopolies come not from Occupy Wall Street types but from leaders of firms seeking freedom of commerce

summary: As pressure builds on companies to address social issues, a single tweet by a basketball executive illustrates the potential costs to having a corporate conscience.

headline: Can a $450 Overcoat Pass for a $3,450 One? A Tailoring Experiment
summary: Thick, tweedy “Mad Men” men’s coats—from luxe labels like Givenchy and Celine—are in style again. We took a bargain vintage piece to a tailor to see if he could approximate the new fit.

headline: Can an AI System Be Given a Patent?
summary: An artificially intelligent system purportedly has created two new products. Now patent offices must decide if it can be named as the inventor.

headline: The Lesson I Learned from Steve Jobs
summary: A challenge from technology’s greatest showman led Marc Benioff to a breakthrough insight about how to find true innovation at Salesforce.com.

headline: These Counties Voted for Every White House Winner Since Reagan
summary: These 19 counties—well less than 1% of the nation’s total—have in the last 10 elections backed Republicans for the White House six times and Democrats four times, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis.

headline: Mutual Funds’ Embrace of High-Profile Unicorns Backfires
summary: Mutual funds that invested billions in big technology startups are now suffering losses in newly public companies and are being forced to mark down their holdings of private companies that are no longer investor darlings.

headline: Many Companies Say They’re Family-Friendly. But It Often Isn’t the Case.
summary: Finding a truly family-friendly workplace requires going beyond an employer’s image. Or even its policies.
